_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Black Gold Farms, is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.



Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety. Black Gold Farms facility is located at 2801 S Marsh Ave. Yorktown, IN. Black Gold Farms is a production facility that produces potato seedlings for potato farmers.  The facility includes but is not limited to shipping and receiving docks, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, miscellaneous utilities, an ammonia refrigeration system that is in the compressor room. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Black Gold Farms is in the process of implementing numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.  Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.

Black Gold Farms Process Safety Management / Risk Management Program has been developed and implemented and is continuously reviewed and updated for effectiveness. This program has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library. 



Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates s

everal policies. Many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.



Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.



Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).



Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.



Operating Procedures: develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines, rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safety perform their tasks in a consistent manner.



Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.



Mechanical Integrity Program: To prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of ammonia, it is important to ensure process equipment is maintained properly. The purpose of an MI

Program is to maintain process equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided or properly contained. The emphasis should be on preventive maintenance rather than breakdown maintenance.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Operations Manager.



Process Hazard Analysis was completed in 2020.  The PHA highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). 



Procedures for conducting Compliance Audits, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Process Hazard Analyses are all part of our PSM/RMP Program.



Volume 2 incorporates information on the specific system components (Pumps, vessels, compressors, evaporators, evaporative condensers, purgers, piping systems, heat exchangers, the emergency ventilation system, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.

Volume 3 incorporates a complete valve list for each system. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.



Also included in Volume 3 is the Process and Instrumentation Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire systems. A block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.



Volume 4 will incorporate a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps

for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.



Volume 5 contains Operation and Maintenance Information including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Black Gold Farms, Yorktown, IN, ammonia refrigeration system is a standard compression and evaporation style systems. Black Gold Farms, is a food-based processing and distribution facility. 



WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE DESCRIPTION

The worst case scenario is of a vessel being ruptured by a forklift or other form of impact.  The alternate case scenario is a pipe rupture on the outlet of an ammonia pump, this could be caused by a forklift or other form of impact.



5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Black Gold Farms, Yorktown, IN, facility has had no reportable releases in the last 5 years. There have been small nuisance odors that have resulted in incident investigations.  



EMERGENCY ACTION CONTINGENCY PLAN

Black Gold Farms has an Emergency Action Contingency Plan to establish procedures and guidelines to provide prompt and orderly action to emergencies involving the release of hazardous materials to prevent or minimize the potential health or environmental effects caused by such a release. The plan utilizes local emergency responders and contractors.



The Plan establishes lines of authority for conducting safe response operat

ions, personnel roles and training, and communication procedures.  All employees are expected to comply with the plan in order to assure its effectiveness.



The plan provides guidelines for determining emergency recognition, proper levels of action, emergency communication, security and control. Guards are setup to monitor alarms from the Ammonia Refrigeration System on a 24/7 basis, ensuring all ammonia related alarms, as well as operational upsets, are responded to immediately.



The Black Gold Farms Emergency Action Contingency Plan involves the preparation of response plans detailed specifically to the Black Gold Farms facility located in Yorktown, Indiana. True emergency response services are available in the community as detailed in the Black Gold Farms Off-Site plan submitted and written by the Delaware County Local Emergency Planning (LEPC) in conjunction with Black Gold Farms emergency planners and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.



Black Gold Farms has a comprehensive emergency response Off-Site Plan that has been written by the Delaware County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) in conjunction with Black Gold Farms emergency planners. The Emergency Action Team is well equipped with chemical sensing equipment, personal protective equipment, and radio communication in order to determine the severity of the release.  This system includes provisions for interaction and support of off-site professional emergency responders.  If above acceptable limits set forth in the Emergency Action Contingency Plan, then local emergency response is called in to handle the situation. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Black Gold Farms is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Black Gold Farms to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
